chapter.htmlHeader: What is the prognosis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Prognosis will depend on the type of poison, the quantity taken, and associated comorbidities.
    • In general, most people will come to no harm after the ingestion of an additional dose of their own medication, or a small amount of a substance of low toxicity [NPIS, 2007].
  • Poisoning in children:
    • Most episodes of accidental ingestion of medicines by preschool children do not cause significant harm. Many children can be managed at home, while others may need to be observed for a short time in hospital [Anderson, 2013].
    • However, severe poisoning does occur. High-risk medications, where ingestion of one or two adult doses could be fatal for a 10 kg toddler, include tricyclic antidepressants, antipsychotics, quinine, calcium channel blockers, beta blockers, antimalarials, theophylline, opioids and oral hypoglycemics [Anderson, 2013].
    • 28 children aged 4 years and under died from unintentional pharmaceutical poisoning between 2001 and 2013. Methadone was associated with over half of these deaths, tricyclic antidepressants with 3 deaths, heroin with 2 deaths, and iron with one death [Anderson, 2016].
    • The most common medicines resulting in ITU admission in children aged 4 and under between 2002-2012 were benzodiazepines and methadone [NPIS, 2016].
  • In 2015, there were 3,674 adult deaths due to drug poisoning registered in England and Wales [ONS, 2016]. 
    • Drug poisoning deaths involve many substances, including legal and illegal drugs, prescription drugs, and over the counter medicines.
    • Over two-thirds of these deaths were males.
    • Half of all deaths involved more than one drug, with or without alcohol. 
    • 447 deaths involved poisoning with antidepressants and 197 poisoning with paracetamol.
  • In 2015, 2,479 of the adult deaths due to drug poisoning registered in England and Wales were due to drug misuse [ONS, 2016]. 
    • Most of these deaths were from accidental poisoning (83% of male deaths and 67% of female deaths).
    • These deaths include those arising from complications of drug misuse, such as sepsis as a result of intravenous drug use.
    • 28% of drug misuse deaths in women were suicides.
    • 11% of drug misuse deaths in men were suicides. 
    • Overall death rates due to drug misuse were higher in men than women (65.5 deaths per million compared with 22.4 deaths per million).
    • The 30-39 year old age group had the highest death rate from drug misuse. This is thought to be due to the fact that heroin users are getting older and frequently have other comorbidities, such as lung disease.
    • 1,201 deaths involved heroin and or morphine, 1,989 involved any opioid, 366 any benzodiazepine and 320 cocaine.
    • The death rate from the misuse of New Psychoactive Substances is increasing. There were 114 deaths associated with these substances. 
    • Note: drug misuse death is defined as when the cause of death is drug abuse or drug dependence, or when the cause of death is drug poisoning and any of the substances controlled under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971 are involved. 
  • Most drug-related deaths in the UK are due to accidental poisonings. Of all the drug-related deaths registered in 2013:
    • 66% of male and 55% of female deaths were due to accidental poisoning [ONS, 2013]. These numbers most likely include cases where the person's intent was unclear, for example in cases of death due to recreational drug use [Sandilands, 2016]. 
    • 41% of the deaths in women were suicides (defined as intentional self-poisoning or self-poisoning where the intent was unclear). For men, this figure was 29% [ONS, 2013].
